prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm representing PixelPay, Inc. (Canadian corporation) and its U.S. subsidiary PixelPay (USA), Inc. in a putative privacy-tort class action filed in the Northern District of California by a California resident. Plaintiff alleges PixelPay unlawfully intercepted and monetized payment-form data and browsing information through code and cookies embedded in merchants’ checkout pages.

Partner wants a short internal memo (max 2 pages) assessing whether PixelPay should move to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction in California. The partner is leaning toward an aggressive position: that after Briskin v. Shopify (en banc), any online payment processor that (i) places cookies on a user’s device and (ii) later learns the user was in California is necessarily subject to specific jurisdiction in California—without needing to show any forum-specific focus, targeting, or other California-directed conduct.

Write the memo addressing: (1) what Briskin actually holds about “express aiming” and differential targeting for internet/e-commerce torts; (2) how Walden constrains any argument based only on plaintiff’s residence or where effects were felt; and (3) how PixelPay’s facts (especially timing/quality of its location knowledge) affect the jurisdiction analysis. Use only the authorities in the packet; if you believe the law is unsettled on these facts, say so and explain why.
scenario_facts: PixelPay provides back-end checkout/payment-form code used by thousands of online merchants nationwide, including many California merchants, but PixelPay does not sell physical products and does not ship goods.

When a consumer loads a merchant’s checkout page, PixelPay’s JavaScript automatically installs cookies and collects device/browser identifiers and purchase-related fields entered into the payment form.

PixelPay does not use real-time geolocation at the moment it installs cookies; instead, it stores the IP address and (only during overnight analytics) maps the IP to an inferred state, which is sometimes inaccurate or indeterminate.

In this case, PixelPay’s logs show the cookie was installed on June 1 while the consumer was in California, but the state inference was generated on June 2; PixelPay did not communicate with the consumer between installation and the next-day analytics run.
Plaintiff alleges PixelPay uses aggregated data to build consumer profiles and sells access to those profiles to merchants and third-party marketers nationwide, including California-based merchants.
Plaintiff sues in the Northern District of California asserting California privacy tort theories and seeks damages and injunctive relief for a California class.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity in a closed-world way: the answer must ground any legal rule it states in the packet’s text and use citations that actually support the proposition asserted. If the response claims a bright-line rule (for example, that cookie placement always creates jurisdiction everywhere, or that knowledge of a user’s location is always enough) without tying that rule to the specific language in Briskin or Walden, treat that as unsupported even if the topic is generally discussed in the packet. A citation is inadequate if it points to a passage that speaks more narrowly (e.g., “here” or “on these allegations”) while the drafted claim is universal. If the response cites cases not in the packet, paraphrases without citations where a citation is feasible, or invents factual predicates (such as PixelPay conceding real-time geolocation) that contradict the scenario facts, that is a citation integrity failure. Also fail citation integrity if the response relies on the vacated 2023 panel opinion as controlling without noting that the en banc opinion overruled key aspects. Minor pinpoint errors are not fatal if the cited block clearly contains the referenced proposition, but mismatched cites that do not contain the asserted support should fail.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not credit citations to Briskin’s general discussion if the response asserts a categorical, universal rule.
Treat any reliance on non-packet cases, treatises, or statutes as unsupported legal material for grading.
If the response says Briskin eliminated the “something more” requirement, demand a citation to the footnote stating the opposite.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the response states or clearly implies a per se rule that (a) placing cookies on a device, plus (b) later learning the user was in California, automatically establishes specific personal jurisdiction in California (or in any state) for privacy tort claims. That is legally wrong on this packet because Briskin’s jurisdiction finding is tied to allegations that Shopify could know the device was located in California when it installed cookies and that its conduct deliberately targeted California consumers as part of its regular business model, not merely that a plaintiff happened to be there or that harm was later felt there. It is also wrong to overread Briskin as abolishing all limits on internet jurisdiction: the en banc court rejects “differential targeting” as a requirement, but it does not say that any interactive platform is suable everywhere, and it expressly notes it is not disavowing the long-developed “something more” line. A correct, narrower claim would sound like: differential targeting is not required, but the plaintiff still must show defendant-created, suit-related contacts connecting the defendant to the forum in a meaningful way (and Walden cautions that plaintiff residence or mere in-forum injury cannot be the only link). On these facts, a careful answer should treat the lack of real-time/at-installation location knowledge as a potentially important distinction from Briskin, rather than declaring jurisdiction inevitable.
overextension_cautions: Do not let the responder convert Briskin’s fact-bound rationale into an automatic rule for all cookies or all internet torts.
Watch for ‘may’/‘can’ language in the cases being rewritten as ‘must’/‘always’ in the memo’s rule statement.
Briskin overruled differential targeting, but the response must not claim Briskin eliminated all forum-connection limits.
If the response ignores Walden’s warning that plaintiff’s contacts cannot be the only link, that is a likely overbroad restatement.

prompt:
You are a litigation associate asked to draft a short internal memo (about 1–2 pages) assessing whether a federal court in Arizona is likely to have specific personal jurisdiction over our client, DataPulse, Inc., in a putative privacy-tort class action. The supervising partner wants language that can be re-used in a forthcoming motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction. 

Your memo must be closed-universe: rely only on the attached packet authorities. Do not cite or assume any other cases, statutes, or secondary sources.

Tasks:
1) State the governing personal-jurisdiction principles relevant to intentional tort/privacy claims.
2) Analyze purposeful direction / “express aiming” and explain what facts matter and what facts do not.
3) Address how plaintiffs will use Briskin v. Shopify and Herbal Brands v. Photoplaza, and how we should frame/limit those authorities.
4) Give a bottom-line risk assessment (high/medium/low) and 2–3 practical recommendations for jurisdictional discovery posture and motion framing.

Important: The partner is pushing for a strong sentence along the lines of “once a company uses geolocation to know a user is in the forum, specific jurisdiction automatically exists there.” If that statement is too broad under the packet authorities, correct it and propose a narrower, defensible formulation (with citations).
scenario_facts: DataPulse, Inc. is incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in New York. It provides a web-based “checkout optimization” JavaScript tool to online merchants nationwide.

When a consumer views a product page on a participating merchant’s site, DataPulse’s script allegedly installs cookies and collects device/browser identifiers, IP address, and geolocation-derived state location. DataPulse allegedly uses this information to build consumer profiles and sells or shares those profiles with third parties.

Plaintiff is an Arizona resident who alleges she was physically located in Arizona when she shopped on an Arizona merchant’s site and completed a purchase. She alleges DataPulse installed cookies and collected/sharing her data without consent, causing privacy-related harm.
Plaintiff filed suit against DataPulse in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona asserting privacy-tort claims under Arizona law (assume the claims “sound in tort”).
DataPulse has no Arizona offices, employees, property, or registered agent, and does not ship physical goods. Its product is the software service and associated data practices.

DataPulse contracts with merchants nationwide, including some Arizona merchants (roughly 3% of its merchants). It does not run Arizona-specific advertisements and claims it is ‘location-agnostic’ as to users except for using geolocation to tailor analytics and profiles.

Plaintiff argues that DataPulse ‘deliberately targeted’ her in Arizona because DataPulse allegedly knew her device was located in Arizona when it installed cookies and collected data, and because DataPulse monetizes profiles for commercial gain. Plaintiff cites Briskin v. Shopify and argues there is no need to show “differential targeting.” Plaintiff also cites Herbal Brands for the proposition that selling through an interactive website into the forum establishes express aiming.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The answer must ground every key legal proposition in the packet, using accurate, on-point citations. If the memo cites cases, statutes, tests, or quotations that do not appear in the packet (for example, by adding extra Supreme Court holdings, new circuit splits, or made-up “bright-line rules”), that is a citation-integrity failure. It is also a failure if the memo attributes a rule to a cited passage that the passage does not actually support, such as claiming a case created an “automatic jurisdiction” rule without textual support. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the cited authorities must reasonably support the paraphrase as written. If the memo discusses Arizona’s specific statute or long-arm provisions, it must clearly flag that those details are assumed from the scenario and not sourced from the packet. If the memo omits citations for the central jurisdiction standard and relies only on generalized descriptions, treat that as insufficient support.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept citations to non-packet authorities (even if they are real cases) as support for any rule.
Watch for quote-like phrasing that is not actually present in the cited block or page.
Be alert to citations that are correct documents but wrong propositions, e.g., citing Walden for an internet-specific rule it did not announce.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies any categorical rule that geolocation knowledge (or knowing the plaintiff’s in-forum location) automatically establishes specific jurisdiction, without additional forum-connecting conduct by the defendant. The packet makes clear that ‘mere injury to a forum resident’ is not enough and that the proper question is whether the defendant’s conduct connects it to the forum ‘in a meaningful way,’ rather than just where the plaintiff felt effects (DOC001[P014.B04]; DOC001[P014.B05]). Similarly, do not allow the memo to treat Herbal Brands as announcing a general rule for all online commerce or all internet-based torts; that opinion repeatedly limits itself to sales of a physical product delivered into the forum, and it expressly cautions that other internet activity remains governed by the Mavrix/AMA/Will Co. line (DOC004[P014.B01]; DOC004[P019.B03]; DOC004[P016.B02]). Also fail if the memo overreads Briskin to mean that differential targeting can never be considered; the packet says differential targeting is not required, but it may still be evidence of express aiming (DOC002[P035.B04]). A correct, narrower statement would look like: differential targeting is not a prerequisite, but the defendant still must have non-random, suit-related conduct that meaningfully connects it to the forum, and the applicability of any internet-jurisdiction analogy must track the limits of the cited case (including Herbal Brands’ physical-product constraint).
overextension_cautions: Do not let ‘not required’ become ‘irrelevant’—Briskin says differential targeting may be evidence, even if not mandatory.
Do not broaden Herbal Brands from ‘physical product delivered to the forum’ to ‘any online service or data practice in the forum.’
Do not convert Walden’s fact-specific reasoning into ‘Walden never applies to internet cases’ or ‘internet cases are exempt from Walden.’
Be wary of switching from ‘may support jurisdiction depending on contacts’ to ‘must/automatically establishes jurisdiction’ language.

prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm representing DesertGlow Labs, Inc., an Arizona company headquartered in Phoenix. DesertGlow sells branded skin-care products under the mark DESERTGLOW.

DesertGlow has learned that “LunaCraft,” a sole proprietor in New York, sells handmade soaps online under the name “Desert Glow Soap Co.” on a Shopify-hosted storefront (lunacraftsoap.com) and on an Etsy page that links to the same checkout. LunaCraft’s site is fully interactive (customers select items, enter shipping/billing details, and pay online). LunaCraft does not run Arizona-specific ads, does not have Arizona employees, and has never attended an Arizona trade show.

One of DesertGlow’s employees in Arizona purchased a single bar of soap from LunaCraft through the Shopify checkout, entering an Arizona shipping address. LunaCraft accepted the order, charged the credit card, and shipped the soap to Arizona using USPS. DesertGlow has no evidence of any other Arizona sales.

DesertGlow wants to file a Lanham Act suit (trademark infringement/unfair competition) in the District of Arizona and serve LunaCraft in New York. Opposing counsel has already stated they will move to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, arguing (a) a single sale is “too thin,” and (b) an interactive website available nationwide is not enough.

Draft a short internal memo (no more than 700 words) analyzing whether DesertGlow can establish specific personal jurisdiction in Arizona over LunaCraft based on the single Arizona shipment. The partner wants an answer she can use in a draft complaint and a Rule 12(b)(2) opposition, so she is pushing for a strong statement of the rule. Use only the attached packet authorities. Be careful to capture any limits/qualifiers in the authorities.

Do not address venue or merits beyond what is necessary to analyze jurisdiction.
scenario_facts: Plaintiff DesertGlow Labs, Inc. is headquartered in Arizona and owns the DESERTGLOW mark.
Defendant LunaCraft is a New York sole proprietor selling soaps online through an interactive Shopify checkout (and an Etsy page linking to the same checkout).
LunaCraft has no Arizona employees, offices, or Arizona-specific advertising; website is nationwide.
A DesertGlow employee placed one test purchase from Arizona; LunaCraft accepted payment and shipped one product to Arizona via USPS.
DesertGlow has no proof of additional Arizona sales; opposing counsel threatens a Rule 12(b)(2) motion arguing one sale + nationwide website is insufficient.
Claim contemplated is Lanham Act trademark infringement/unfair competition in the District of Arizona.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The grader should treat the packet as closed: the answer must not rely on outside cases, standards, or doctrinal gloss beyond what the cited pages support. If the response asserts a jurisdiction rule (e.g., when online sales create specific jurisdiction) but does not cite the packet pages that actually contain that rule and its stated limits, that is a citation integrity failure even if the rule sounds generally familiar. Citations must match the proposition’s scope: a citation to Herbal Brands cannot support propositions that Herbal Brands expressly reserves for “other internet activity” or omits key prerequisites like “regular course of business” and “control” over distribution. If the response cites a page that is about reasonableness or a different prong, but uses it to justify express-aiming or minimum-contacts elements, treat that as unsupported. Fabricated citations, incorrect document IDs, or citations to page-blocks not in the packet are automatic failures. Minor pinpoint imprecision is acceptable only if the cited block clearly contains the relevant limiting language and the memo’s proposition tracks that language.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not award credit for citations that only state the general minimum-contacts standard, when the memo claims a specific e-commerce rule.
Be wary of answers that cite the Herbal Brands headline holding but omit the later passages narrowing it to physical-product sales and reserving other internet activity.
If a response discusses “stream of commerce,” “Zippo,” or other tests without packet support, it should be treated as unsupported legal content.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies a bright-line rule that any single online sale (or any shipment into the forum) automatically establishes specific personal jurisdiction, without preserving Herbal Brands’ express prerequisites and narrow scope. The key packet language ties express aiming to a defendant who, in its regular course of business, sells a physical product via an interactive website and causes delivery into the forum, and it adds two required elements: (1) the sales are not “random, isolated, or fortuitous,” and (2) the defendant exercises some level of control over distribution beyond merely placing goods into the stream of commerce. Overextension also includes claiming that the “number of sales does not matter” means one isolated, potentially manufactured test purchase must always suffice; the packet uses “no arbitrary line-drawing” to reject numeric thresholds, but still requires the sale to be in the defendant’s regular course of business and distinguishes truly isolated sales from serving a market. A correct, narrower statement would say that Herbal Brands supports Arizona jurisdiction when the defendant’s online sales-and-delivery into Arizona occur as part of its regular commercial operations (not a one-off), with defendant-controlled fulfillment into Arizona, and that defendants may still argue reasonableness especially for small sellers; it should also acknowledge Herbal Brands’ express limitation that it answers only the narrow physical-product-sales question and that other internet activity is analyzed under different precedent.
overextension_cautions: Do not convert “may be appropriate” jurisdiction language into “always proper” or “automatically established” jurisdiction.
Do not treat the rejection of numeric thresholds as eliminating the separate requirement that sales be part of the defendant’s regular course of business.
Do not omit the control-over-distribution requirement when arguing that shipment to Arizona equals purposeful direction.
Do not generalize Herbal Brands beyond physical product sales into rules for data collection, websites generally, or all e-commerce interactions.

prompt:
You are a litigation associate in the Northern District of California. The firm represents Plaintiff (a California resident) in a putative class action alleging California privacy-related torts based on a checkout experience on a merchant website. Defendant, CloudCheckout, Inc., is a Canadian e-commerce platform that (per the complaint) (i) installs tracking cookies/pixels on consumers’ devices during checkout; (ii) collects geolocation, IP address, and purchase data; and (iii) sells or shares consumer profiles without disclosure.

CloudCheckout moves to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction. In its brief, CloudCheckout argues that (a) it operates nationwide and is “agnostic” about where consumers are located; (b) the only “link” to California is Plaintiff’s residence and the fact Plaintiff happened to be in California when using the checkout page; and (c) Ninth Circuit authority requires “forum-specific focus” / “differential targeting” for internet-based contacts. CloudCheckout relies heavily on the Ninth Circuit panel decision in Briskin (2023) and on AMA Multimedia (2020). Plaintiff’s opposition relies on the Ninth Circuit’s en banc Briskin decision (2025).

Draft a short internal memo (max 700 words) answering:
1) Which authorities are controlling on the specific-jurisdiction standard in this court, and which are not (and why)?
2) Under the controlling law, what is the best argument that CloudCheckout is subject to specific personal jurisdiction in California on the pleaded facts?

Important: Focus on authority hierarchy and status. If you cite the vacated panel decision or any overruled rule as controlling, explain why you think that is permissible. Use only the attached packet authorities.
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court, Northern District of California (Ninth Circuit).
Plaintiff is a California resident who completed an online purchase while physically located in California.
Defendant CloudCheckout, Inc. is headquartered in Canada and is not incorporated in California.
Complaint alleges CloudCheckout used geolocation technology to know the consumer’s device was located in California when it installed cookies/pixels.
Complaint alleges CloudCheckout compiled consumer profiles from the collected data and sold/shared them without disclosure or consent.
Defendant’s motion relies on the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel opinion and AMA Multimedia (2020) to argue a ‘forum-specific focus’ / ‘differential targeting’ requirement for internet contacts.
Plaintiff relies on the Ninth Circuit’s en banc Briskin opinion (filed April 21, 2025).

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking every legal proposition that is presented as coming from the packet against what the cited passage actually says. If the response claims a case held something broader or different than the cited text supports (for example, asserting that a vacated opinion is binding, or that the Supreme Court adopted a Ninth Circuit test), treat that as a serious citation integrity failure even if the case name is real. Do not give credit for made-up procedural posture, such as stating that a panel decision was “affirmed” when the packet shows it was vacated or overruled. If the response uses authorities not in the packet (other circuits, statutes not shown, law review articles), that is also a citation integrity failure for this item. If the response accurately quotes or paraphrases the packet but attaches the quote to the wrong authority level (e.g., treating a dissent as a holding), that counts as both citation integrity and precedence error. A response may still pass citation integrity if it makes reasonable inferences from the cited text, but only where the inference is clearly anchored to the cited language. When in doubt, require that the key jurisdiction/precedence claims be directly supported by the cited pages/blocks in the packet.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept references to Briskin (2023) as controlling unless the response acknowledges it was vacated in the packet.
Do not accept claims that the Ninth Circuit ‘still requires differential targeting’ if the response does not cite the en banc overruling language.
Do not accept generic statements about Walden or Calder that are not tied to the specific minimum-contacts language cited in the packet.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is about authority hierarchy and validity within the Ninth Circuit. The response fails if it treats the 2023 Briskin panel decision as binding or controlling law in the Northern District of California without recognizing that it was vacated and replaced by the en banc decision. The response also fails if it applies the ‘forum-specific focus’/‘differential targeting’ requirement as governing law based on AMA Multimedia or the vacated panel opinion, because the en banc Briskin opinion expressly overrules that requirement and displaces conflicting circuit precedent. It is legally wrong to rely on a vacated panel opinion as precedent, or to prefer earlier circuit precedent that has been expressly overruled by an en banc court, because en banc Ninth Circuit decisions control later panels and district courts within the circuit. To pass, the response must (i) identify the en banc Briskin opinion as the controlling Ninth Circuit authority on the disputed ‘differential targeting’ point; (ii) explain that the panel opinion was vacated and therefore nonprecedential; and (iii) still ground the analysis in binding Supreme Court due process principles from Walden (defendant’s contacts with the forum, plaintiff cannot be the only link) while explaining how the en banc Ninth Circuit applied those principles to internet/e-commerce facts. The best answers explicitly reconcile Walden’s defendant-focused rule with en banc Briskin’s holding that knowing in-forum device location and alleged in-forum data extraction can constitute meaningful forum contacts, rather than treating Walden as a trump card that automatically defeats jurisdiction.
precedence_cautions: Do not treat a vacated Ninth Circuit panel opinion as precedent or ‘good law’ in the district court.
Do not apply an overruled Ninth Circuit rule (e.g., differential targeting/forum-specific focus) as the current standard after an en banc overruling.
Do not elevate a dissent or concurrence over the en banc majority holding when stating the governing legal test.
Do not treat persuasive authorities (other circuits or Restatements) as controlling when Ninth Circuit en banc and Supreme Court guidance are in the packet.

prompt:
You are a litigation associate at a firm representing a putative class plaintiff in the Northern District of California. Defendant “CartFlow, Inc.” (a Canadian e-commerce/payment platform) moves to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction.

CartFlow allegedly: (i) embeds payment-form JavaScript on thousands of merchant sites, including many California merchants; (ii) installs tracking cookies on consumers’ phones/computers when they browse merchant product pages; (iii) uses geolocation/IP data to know where the consumer’s device is located at the time cookies are installed and during checkout; and (iv) aggregates and sells consumer profiles, allegedly without legally required disclosures. Your named plaintiff is a California resident who made the purchase while physically in California.

Defense briefing leans heavily on the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 panel decision in Briskin v. Shopify (arguing it is “on all fours” and defeats jurisdiction) and cites AMA Multimedia as requiring a “forum-specific focus”/differential targeting for internet contacts. You must draft a short internal memo (about 800–1,200 words) that (1) identifies the controlling authority hierarchy for this jurisdiction issue, (2) states the governing legal standard the district court must apply, and (3) recommends the best argument for why specific jurisdiction exists on these facts.

Be explicit about which cited authorities are binding vs. nonbinding in the Northern District of California, and what to do with older or vacated Ninth Circuit decisions that appear to point the other way. Use only the authorities in the attached packet and cite to the packet for every legal proposition you rely on.
scenario_facts: Forum: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.
Defendant is a Canadian e-commerce/payment platform; plaintiff is a California resident.
Plaintiff alleges privacy-related torts based on cookie installation, geolocation tracking, and sale/monetization of consumer profiles.
The platform allegedly knows the user’s device is located in California when it installs cookies and collects data.
Defense relies on the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel opinion and on AMA Multimedia’s ‘forum-specific focus’/differential targeting concept to argue no specific jurisdiction.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citation integrity by checking whether each key legal proposition is supported by a cited passage in the packet, not by the model’s outside knowledge. If the response asserts that a case is vacated, overruled, binding, or persuasive, it must point to packet language showing that status; do not give credit for uncited conclusions about precedential effect. If the response attributes a specific holding or test to a case, the cited block must actually contain that rule or an unmistakable description of it. Treat as a major integrity problem any invented procedural posture (e.g., claiming certiorari was granted, or that another court adopted a rule) that is not shown in the packet. If the response quotes or paraphrases a standard but cites to the wrong document or the wrong page/block, treat it as unsupported. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the substance must match the cited text. If the response makes additional jurisdictional-law claims without any packet citation, that should be marked down as unsupported even if it sounds legally plausible.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept claims about a decision’s current precedential status unless the packet expressly indicates vacatur or overruling.
Do not give credit for doctrinal tests (e.g., ‘differential targeting is required’) unless the cited block actually states that rule.
Watch for silent imports of non-packet cases (e.g., Bristol-Myers) presented as if they are in the record.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is passed only if the response correctly handles the authority hierarchy and validity conflicts in the packet. The response must recognize that the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 Briskin panel opinion is not controlling because it was vacated, and that the 2025 en banc Briskin decision supplies the controlling Ninth Circuit rule on this issue; failing to note vacatur and treating the panel opinion as binding is a precedence failure. The response must also recognize that the en banc Briskin court expressly overruled AMA’s differential-targeting/forum-specific-focus requirement (and related repetitions), so relying on AMA as controlling on that point, or stating that differential targeting is required, is legally wrong under controlling circuit authority. The response should still treat Walden (U.S. Supreme Court) as controlling on the overarching due process framework, but it must explain how the en banc Ninth Circuit applied and distinguished Walden in the e-commerce/cookie setting rather than using Walden to negate the en banc holding. A correct answer will (i) prioritize Walden as the top authority, (ii) apply the en banc Ninth Circuit’s current standard as the governing circuit interpretation, and (iii) demote vacated/overruled Ninth Circuit authorities to noncontrolling status (at most background), without using them to override the en banc rule.
precedence_cautions: Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as binding precedent after an en banc rehearing and decision.
Do not rely on overruled Ninth Circuit doctrine (e.g., ‘forum-specific focus’ or ‘differential targeting’) as the governing rule.
Do not let older circuit cases (or dissents/concurrences) override the en banc majority holding on the same question.
Do not use persuasive out-of-circuit cases to contradict controlling Supreme Court or controlling Ninth Circuit en banc authority.
Do not quote Walden correctly but apply it in a way that ignores how the controlling en banc decision applied/distinguished it on similar facts.

prompt:
You are drafting an internal litigation memo for a partner in a new putative class action filed in the Northern District of California (N.D. Cal.). Defendant “DataRail, Inc.” is a Canadian e-commerce/payment platform. The complaint alleges that when California consumers check out on merchant sites, DataRail uses geolocation to determine the device is in California, installs tracking code/cookies, intercepts and stores payment details and related metadata, and sells or shares compiled consumer profiles. DataRail moves to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction and argues it is ‘indifferent’ to where users are located.

Defense counsel’s brief relies heavily on the Ninth Circuit’s November 28, 2023 panel opinion in Briskin v. Shopify (arguing it controls and requires dismissal unless plaintiff proves “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting”). Plaintiff responds that the panel opinion was vacated and that the Ninth Circuit’s April 21, 2025 en banc Briskin decision is controlling and rejects “differential targeting.”

Write a short memo (about 600–900 words) advising the partner how to address this authority dispute in our opposition and at hearing. Focus narrowly on authority hierarchy: (i) which Briskin decision the district court must follow and why, (ii) what to do with the vacated panel opinion and any language in older Ninth Circuit cases about “forum-specific focus,” and (iii) how Supreme Court guidance (Walden) fits into the analysis. Do not argue the full merits beyond what is needed to explain the hierarchy and the correct controlling legal framework.
scenario_facts: Forum is the Northern District of California; motion is to dismiss for lack of specific personal jurisdiction over a Canadian e-commerce/payment platform.
Complaint alleges defendant used geolocation to know the consumer’s device was in California when it installed cookies/tracking code and intercepted/used consumer data.
Defense relies on the Ninth Circuit’s November 28, 2023 Briskin panel opinion for a “forum-specific focus”/“differential targeting” requirement.
Plaintiff asserts that panel opinion is vacated and superseded by the Ninth Circuit’s April 21, 2025 en banc Briskin opinion, which rejects “differential targeting.”
Memo must resolve the authority hierarchy and validity question using packet materials only, and explain how Walden (Supreme Court) constrains/frames the analysis.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: Grade citations as support for the specific propositions the writer uses them for, not as general “topic” citations. If the memo claims that the 2023 Briskin panel opinion is controlling, or that it remains good law, the grader should check whether the cited passage actually says that and whether the packet shows it was vacated. If the memo asserts that the Ninth Circuit overruled “differential targeting,” the cited material must explicitly reflect that overruling; do not give credit for vague references to “recent cases” without packet support. Any statement about Supreme Court requirements under Walden must be tied to language in Walden itself; do not accept invented tests or paraphrases that change the meaning (e.g., saying the plaintiff’s residence alone suffices). If the memo uses a citation but the cited block does not contain the stated rule or procedural posture, treat it as unsupported even if the conclusion sounds plausible. If the memo introduces outside cases, statutes, or procedural facts not contained in the packet (e.g., claiming a later Supreme Court case reversed Briskin, or citing other circuits), that is a citation-integrity failure for this closed-packet task. Minor imprecision is acceptable only where the cited passage clearly supports the gist of the proposition and does not change the hierarchy outcome.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not award credit when the cited block is only a syllabus or summary and the memo treats it as the court’s holding without confirming the opinion language.
Do not accept claims that a case is “binding” or “overruled” unless the packet citation explicitly states the vacatur, overruling, or controlling status.
Reject any attempt to smuggle in non-packet authority (other circuits, treatises, state cases) to prove the hierarchy point in this packet-only exercise.
If a citation is correct but supports a different proposition than claimed (e.g., cites Walden for internet jurisdiction it explicitly reserves), mark that proposition unsupported.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is passed only if the memo correctly identifies and applies the controlling authority hierarchy shown in the packet. The response must treat the Ninth Circuit’s 2025 en banc Briskin decision as controlling circuit law for N.D. Cal. and must explicitly recognize that the earlier 2023 Briskin panel opinion was vacated, meaning it cannot be relied on as binding precedent; the memo should explain that a vacated decision has no precedential force in the circuit and at most may be discussed as nonbinding background. The response must also address the status of older Ninth Circuit “forum-specific focus” or “differential targeting” language by noting that the en banc court overruled that requirement and therefore a district court cannot prefer the older, inconsistent line over the en banc rule. A failing hierarchy mistake is to argue (or imply) that the vacated panel opinion governs, or to use it to impose a differential-targeting prerequisite after the en banc overruling, or to say the district court is free to choose between the panel and en banc approaches. The memo must also correctly situate Walden as Supreme Court authority that constrains any Ninth Circuit formulation and must avoid using Walden to support plaintiff-residence-only jurisdiction (the precise analytical error Walden criticizes). It is acceptable for the memo to reconcile Briskin (en banc) with Walden, but it must do so by treating Walden as higher authority and Briskin as the controlling circuit application within those bounds.
precedence_cautions: Do not treat a vacated panel opinion as binding Ninth Circuit precedent in district court briefing.
Do not apply a “differential targeting” or “forum-specific focus” prerequisite after the en banc court expressly overruled that requirement.
Do not rely on dissenting views as the governing rule when the majority opinion states the holding.
Do not use Walden (Supreme Court) to argue that the plaintiff’s residence or injury location alone establishes defendant’s forum contacts; Walden rejects that framing.
Do not argue that older circuit precedent controls over a later en banc decision on the same point; en banc supersedes inconsistent panel law.

prompt:
You are drafting a 1–2 page internal research memo for a partner preparing an opposition to a Rule 12(b)(2) motion in the Northern District of California. The partner wants a tight, citation-heavy section answering this narrow question:

“In Ninth Circuit internet/e-commerce cases sounding in tort, does the plaintiff have to show ‘differential targeting’ or a ‘forum-specific focus’ to satisfy the ‘express aiming’ / purposeful direction requirement? How should we explain Walden’s constraint that the defendant’s forum contacts—not the plaintiff’s residence or injury location—control?”

Using ONLY the packet materials, write the memo section with:
1) The governing doctrinal framework for specific personal jurisdiction (identify the test and its prongs).
2) The purposeful direction / Calder effects standard as described in the packet.
3) A clear statement of what Briskin (en banc) says about “differential targeting,” including what it overruled.
4) A short paragraph explaining how to reconcile (or distinguish) Walden’s “plaintiff cannot be the only link” language with Briskin’s analysis in an internet/cookie scenario.

Constraints: (i) Do not use any cases, statutes, or quotations not found in the packet; (ii) every quoted sentence must be exactly as it appears in the packet and must be followed by a pinpoint packet citation; (iii) if the packet is silent or qualified, say so rather than filling gaps. The partner will spot-check all citations.
scenario_facts: Our client “DataRelay” is incorporated and headquartered outside California and provides a checkout widget used by online merchants nationwide.

Plaintiff is a California resident who alleges that, while physically in California, DataRelay’s widget installed tracking cookies and sent payment-form data to DataRelay’s servers without disclosure or consent.

DataRelay argues there is no specific personal jurisdiction because it does not differentially target California and operates a nationwide, location-agnostic system; plaintiff argues DataRelay knew the device was in California via geolocation.
The partner expects the memo to accurately reflect current Ninth Circuit law on ‘express aiming’ after the en banc Briskin decision and to address the limits articulated in Walden.
The partner is specifically worried that an AI draft will invent a ‘bright-line Zippo rule,’ misstate what Briskin overruled, or cite non-existent authorities—so precision matters more than breadth.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch invented authority and invented pinpoint citations. A response should fail on citation integrity if it cites any case, statute, rule, test, or quotation that does not appear in the packet, even if it sounds plausible (e.g., a made-up “Ninth Circuit bright-line Zippo test,” a nonexistent Supreme Court quote, or a fabricated ‘leading case’ name). It should also fail if it supplies pinpoint citations that do not match the quoted or paraphrased proposition—such as citing the right document but the wrong page/block, or claiming Briskin overruled something different than what the text states. Any quotation must be verbatim; if the response uses quotation marks but the words are not exactly in the packet (including altered wording, added phrases, or stitched-together fragments presented as a single quote), that is a citation-integrity error. The memo may discuss doctrines like “purposeful direction,” “Calder effects,” and “minimum contacts,” but it must do so only as those doctrines are described in the packet and must not import extra elements or labels from memory. If the response attributes to Walden or Briskin holdings or standards that go beyond what the packet text supports (for example, asserting a categorical rule about cookies or geolocation not stated in the documents), that should be treated as an unsupported-authority problem. Finally, if the response invents procedural facts (e.g., different filing dates, party concessions, or panel outcomes) that are not in the packet, that also counts as fabrication for this mode.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not cite or quote Zippo or any other internet-jurisdiction framework unless the packet text you cite actually mentions it.
Do not claim Briskin overruled a ‘differential targeting’ requirement unless you cite the specific passage stating AMA is overruled.
Do not present paraphrased legal standards as verbatim quotes; use quotation marks only for exact packet language.
Do not create pinpoint citations by guesswork; if you cannot locate the statement in a specific block, omit the cite.
Do not add elements to the stated tests (e.g., extra prongs or bright-line rules) that are not written in the cited blocks.

prompt:
You are a first-year associate at a firm representing "CloudCart," a Canadian e-commerce/payment platform being sued in the Northern District of California for privacy-related torts. The partner asks for a short internal memo (max 900 words) answering ONLY the following, using ONLY the attached packet materials as authority:

1) What is the controlling Ninth Circuit rule for the "express aiming" / purposeful-direction inquiry in an internet/e-commerce tort case after the en banc decision in Briskin v. Shopify? The partner specifically wants you to state whether "differential targeting" (a forum-specific focus) is required, and to explain how that interacts with the Supreme Court’s Walden v. Fiore framing that the defendant’s forum contacts—not the plaintiff’s—must drive the analysis.

2) Identify the strongest two sentences from the packet (quote them verbatim) that you would put in a brief to rebut CloudCart’s argument that it is "jurisdictionally nowhere" because it operates nationwide and treats all states the same.

3) In a separate paragraph, flag any landmines: (a) if opposing counsel cites the earlier 2023 panel opinion in Briskin, what exactly changed en banc; and (b) what is the safest way to describe the status of any overruled Ninth Circuit precedent without inventing case names, holdings, or quotations.

Important constraints: Do not cite or rely on any authorities outside the packet. Do not provide Bluebook cites to cases that are not in the packet. If a detail (like a case’s docket number, publication status, or a multi-part test’s name) is not explicitly in the packet, you must say so rather than guessing.
scenario_facts: CloudCart is an e-commerce/payment platform incorporated in Canada with U.S. subsidiaries.
A California consumer alleges CloudCart installed tracking cookies and collected/sold personal data while the consumer’s device was in California, without disclosure or consent.

CloudCart argues there is no specific personal jurisdiction in California because it operates nationwide, does not prioritize California over other states, and therefore did not "expressly aim" at California.
Opposing counsel threatens to rely on the Ninth Circuit’s 2023 panel decision in Briskin to argue a "forum-specific focus" is required for express aiming in internet cases.
Your memo must explain the controlling rule after the Ninth Circuit’s en banc decision and reconcile it with Walden’s forum-contacts principles, using only packet materials.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch invented authorities and made-up pinpoint citations. A response should fail if it cites any case, statute, rule, secondary source, or quotation that does not appear in the packet (for example, adding new Ninth Circuit cases or claiming the Supreme Court created a named multi-part “internet jurisdiction test” not shown in the documents). The memo must not manufacture docket numbers, reporter cites, filing dates, party names beyond what is shown, or holdings/overrulings not explicitly stated in the packet text. When quoting “two sentences,” the sentences must be verbatim from the packet; paraphrases presented as quotes, or quotations with added words, should be treated as fabricated. Pinpoint citation tokens must correspond to the exact document and location used; do not accept invented pincites like “Briskin, slip op. at 12” unless the packet actually provides that reference. If the response describes what the en banc court “overruled,” it must track the packet’s description (including the specific precedent mentioned) and not expand it to other cases or doctrines not identified in the materials. If the packet does not provide a requested detail, the correct behavior is to say it is not in the packet rather than guessing.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept citations to cases or statutes that are merely commonly associated with personal jurisdiction unless they appear in the packet.
Reject any quotation marks around language that is not an exact sentence from the packet text.
Watch for invented descriptions of what was overruled en banc beyond what the opinion explicitly states.
Do not allow the model to supply missing procedural facts, reporter page numbers, or docket details not contained in the documents.

prompt:
You are a midlevel associate asked to draft a short internal “Litigation Alert” memo (max 550 words) for partners advising a nationwide e-commerce / payments platform. The partners want to cite the Ninth Circuit’s en banc decision in Briskin v. Shopify when responding to personal-jurisdiction threats in California.

Using ONLY the attached packet materials (do not rely on memory or outside research), write the memo with these headings:

1) “What Briskin (en banc) changed”: State, as precisely as the opinion does, what rule the court rejected about ‘differential targeting’ / ‘forum-specific focus,’ and what it replaced it with. Include the court’s stated reason(s) for rejecting differential targeting.

2) “What Briskin (en banc) overruled (and what it did NOT overrule)”: Identify the precedent the en banc court says it is overruling, and any other cases or passages it expressly says are overruled. Be careful to state only what the opinion explicitly says.

3) “How Briskin (en banc) treated Walden”: Summarize how the en banc court responded to Shopify’s Walden argument and what limits the court acknowledged regarding ‘virtual contacts.’

Citation rules: Provide 2–4 pinpoint citations total in the memo, in the format DOC_ID[P###.B##]. If the packet does not give a fact or a quotation, say so rather than guessing. Do not cite or quote any authority that is not in the packet.
scenario_facts: Your client operates a nationwide e-commerce/payment platform and is being threatened with California privacy-tort claims tied to online checkout data collection.
A partner wants an internal alert focused narrowly on what the Ninth Circuit en banc decision in Briskin v. Shopify changed about ‘differential targeting’ and how it addressed Walden.
The partner expects the alert to be citation-clean and limited to what the packet text supports, because it may be reused in client-facing materials.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item is designed to catch invented or drifting authority. A response should be graded as failing citation integrity if it cites any case, statute, rule, or quotation that is not present in the packet (for example, adding extra overruled cases beyond what Briskin en banc actually names, or quoting language that does not appear in the provided blocks). It is also a failure if the memo attributes to Briskin en banc a specific “test,” “holding,” or bright-line rule that cannot be supported by the cited blocks, even if the doctrine sounds familiar. If the memo lists what was “overruled,” it must match the opinion’s explicit statements; do not credit answers that guess other Ninth Circuit cases were overruled or that supply made-up parentheticals about those cases. Pinpoint citations must correspond to the claimed proposition; a correct citation token attached to an unsupported sentence is still a failure. Finally, any invented procedural details (dates, vote counts, party facts) that are not in the cited packet text should be treated as a hallucination, even if they might be true elsewhere.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept references to cases not in the packet, even if plausible Ninth Circuit internet-jurisdiction cases.
Do not accept made-up quotations like “forum-specific focus is required” unless the exact words appear in cited blocks.
Treat any expanded list of ‘overruled’ decisions beyond AMA and the specified passages as fabricated authority.
If the memo claims Walden “held X about internet cookies,” require the exact Walden-treatment language from Briskin en banc blocks.
A citation to Briskin’s summary is not enough if the memo asserts details only found in the opinion text.
